all.definition: The Wagner Act established the National Labor Relations Act (1935) and affirms workers' rights to bargain collectively through chosen agents.
The NLRB is an independent federal agency established by the Wagner Act to enforce labor laws and oversee union elections.
The Social Security Act (1935) required American workers to pay a social security tax, providing benefits upon reaching retirement age.
This Supreme Court case ruled that a state can set minimum wage laws, overturning the previous notion of the Liberty of Contract.

all.concept: NLRB v. Jones and Laughlin Steel
all.definition: In this Supreme Court case, the court ruled that Congress can regulate labor relations as all commerce is inherently interstate.
The Fair Labor Standards Act (1938) established the federally mandated 8-hour workday and 40-hour workweek, along with the federal minimum wage.
The WPA (Works Progress Administration) was a federal agency that financed public infrastructure projects to create employment during the Great Depression.
